thread.section_title: National News -  New York Daily News
thread.title: Muslim-American raising funds to help repair Jewish cemetery
thread.title_full: Muslim-American raising funds to help repair Jewish cemetery

author: ELIZABETH ELIZALDE
title: Muslim-American raising funds to help repair Jewish cemetery

organizations.name: arab american association of new york

text:
American Muslims quickly raise over $35,000 for a desecrated Jewish cemetary in St. Louis. (Launch Good) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS  41 PM 
After dozens of tombstones at a historic Jewish St. Louis cemetery were vandalized over the weekend, Muslim-American activists started a fundraiser to help pay for repairs. 
“Every person deserves to rest in peace,” activist and campaign organizer, Tarek El-Messidi, told the Daily News Tuesday. “No one wants to see the grave of their loved ones desecrated.” 
When El-Messidi first learned vandals damaged more than 100 headstones at the Chesed Shel Emeth Cemetery in University City, he immediately reached its director to talk about campaign ideas and the best ways to provide financial assistance. 
There have been no arrests. Sally Amon and her son Max Amon of Olivette, Mo., react as they saw toppled gravestone of her grandmother Anna Ida Hutkin at Chesed Shel Emeth Cemetery in University City, a suburb of St. Louis on Tuesday, Feb. 21, 2017. Vandals have damaged or tipped over as many as 200 headstones at the Jewish cemetery in suburban St. Louis, leaving the region's Jewish community shaken and anxious. (Robert Cohen/St. Louis Post-Dispatch via AP) (Robert Cohen/AP) 
The incident reminded him of a story about the Prophet Mohammed, who stood during a Jewish funeral procession. When his disciples asked why, he said: “Is it not a human soul?” 
The campaign organized by Linda Sarsour, of MPower Change, and El-Messidi, of Celebrate Mercy, raised more than $30,000 within hours of launching Tuesday. 
“Through this campaign, we hope to send a united message from the Jewish and Muslim communities that there is no place for this type of hate, desecration, and violence in America,” the fundraising page on LauchingGood reads. Vandals damaged over 150 headstones at Chesed Shel Emeth Cemetery in University City, MO. on February 20, 2017. *** Local Caption *** http://www.ksdk.com/news/local/headstones-damaged-at-jewish-cemetery1/410194492 (KSDK) 
“We pray that this restores a sense of security and peace to the Jewish-American community who has undoubtedly been shaken by this event.” 
El-Messidi said the spike in anti-Semitism and Islamophobia have stemmed from President Trump’s campaign vow to ban Muslims from entering the U.S. after the San Bernardino shooting. 
His organization created the “Muslims United for San Bernardino” campaign in Dec. 2015, which raised more than $200,000, for victims’ families. Spencer Pensoneau, center, and Ron Klump of Rosenbloom Monument Company re-set stones at Chesed Shel Emeth Cemetery in University City, mMo., on Tuesday, Feb. 21, 2017 where almost 200 gravestones were vandalized over the weekend. (Robert Cohen/St. Louis Post-Dispatch via AP) (Robert Cohen/AP) 
“This is something that Celebrate Mercy is passionate about,” he said. 
Sarsour, who’s also executive director of the Arab American Association of New York, told The News that New York City Councilmember Brad Lander, who grew up in St. Louis, connected her with the synagogue affiliated with the cemetery. 
The $20,000 raised will go the cemetery, and the rest would go to other Jewish centers if “God forbid something else were to happen,” Sarsour said. 
“We’re unfortunately living under one of the most anti-Semitic and Islamophobic administrations in history and I’m a afraid of more attacks on Muslim and Jewish centers,” she said. “But I’m seeing a lot more cooperation among our communities. That may be the light in this darkness that we see.” Join the Conversation:
